title: Logical NOR
summary:
In boolean logic, logical nor or joint denial is a truth-functional operator which produces a result that is the negation of logical or.  That is, a sentence of the form (p NOR q) is true precisely when neither p nor q is true—i.e. when both of p and q are false. It is logically equivalent to ¬ ( p ∨ q ) {\displaystyle 
eg (p\lor q)} and ¬ p ∧ ¬ q {\displaystyle 
eg p\land 
eg q} , where the symbol ¬ {\displaystyle 
eg } signifies logical negation, ∨ {\displaystyle \lor } signifies OR, and ∧ {\displaystyle \land } signifies AND.
